The Causes and Conditions of the Great Elder of RÄjagá¹›ha Realizing Pratyekabodhi
Just as in a dense forest, one wishes to pull out a large tree,
The branches and trunks obstruct each other, and there is no way to get out.
Living at home is like a dense forest, and many affairs are like branches and trunks.
Although one wishes to seek the essential path to leaving home, one is bound and attached without any cause.
In a quiet place in the forest, contemplate the realm and cultivate one's mind,
Liberate oneself from many conditions and affairs, and leave behind all loved ones.
Cultivate the practice of going alone, like a rhinoceros horn without a second,
The former teachers transmitted it to each other, and I have heard this matter.

In the past, there was a pratyekabuddha who always cultivated various wholesome deeds in the presence of the five past buddhas. He was an upÄsaka who enjoyed being attached to household affairs. Although he saw the buddhas, he did not seek to leave home.
However, he single-mindedly upheld the lay precepts without any transgression.

His wholesome roots gradually increased, and he left home to study the Way under KÄÅ›yapa Buddha. He enjoyed cultivating ascetic practices, possessing the six objects, and detested desires. When his life ended, he was reborn in the heavenly palace.
When his heavenly lifespan ended, he was reborn in the home of a great elder in RÄjagá¹›ha. This elder's family was immeasurably wealthy, with overflowing storehouses.
As he gradually grew up and reached adulthood, after his father's death he enjoyed pleasures as he wished, like VaiÅ›ravaá¹‡a's son NalakÅ«bara.

In his own home, he enjoyed various affairs, had thirty sons and daughters each, had a very large number of servants and retainers, and had many marriages for his sons and daughters. He only focused on the present and forgot the Dharma he had cultivated.
Bound by various affairs, he did not abandon his family business. He heard from his servants that many relatives had died, and that a certain daughter's home had suffered a disaster and lost her job.
Hearing such news of loss, he was sorrowful and distressed, as if a hundred arrows had pierced his heart at once.
He also heard pleasant and endearing words, that the family's merchant had obtained precious treasures and returned safely, and that his son had given birth to a boy.
He also heard that his own daughter had given birth to a fortunate child, and he rejoiced again.
Hearing of the decline and loss, sorrow and joy mixed together, like a turning wheel in a performance.

He went with a close friend to a garden, and while strolling he came to a grove and saw a man cutting down a large tree. The branches, twigs, and leaves were luxuriant, and many elephants pulling it could not get it out;
He cut down a small tree without any branches or twigs, and a single person pulled it out without any obstruction, and then pulled it out of the grove.
Having seen this, he thought to himself and said:
I have now seen the causes and conditions.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
I see a great tree being felled, with abundant branches and leaves,
Entangled and obstructed by the dense forest, unable to escape.
The world is also like this, with sons, daughters, and relatives,
Love and hatred bind the mind, in the dense forest of birth and death,
One cannot attain liberation;
A small tree without branches and twigs cannot be obstructed by the dense forest.
Cutting off affection and love, in the dense forest of birth and death,
One will naturally attain liberation.
He then attained the path of pratyekabuddha-hood right there.
At that time, his friend said to him,
The sun is setting, let us return home together.
He replied to his friend,
You may return home on your own.
I have already cut off the causes for returning home.
His friend asked,
How have you cut them off?
He replied,
In the past, I was attached to family life because of love. Now I have already cut off such loving actions.

The people's beloved possessions, wives, children, and relatives, young sons and grandchildren, out of love and indulgence, when seeing their father, make noises and are unable to be understood, and run around clinging to things. Because of this, love and attachment arise.
I have completely put an end to such a loving mind towards my wives, children, and relatives.

When I was originally at home, I managed various affairs, sometimes going out and sometimes coming in, sometimes saying to give this and sometimes saying to take that, sometimes saying it should be done and sometimes saying it should not be done.

Such matters I have now cut off. I have abandoned the pleasures of desire and attained the bliss of liberation, cut the roots of the tree of craving, closed the doors to the realms of existence, and extinguished the great darkness of obstructions.
I am now like an enemy to my children, no different.
How can I now return home like this?
Then his close friend returned home and told his son and daughter.
The son and daughter, young and old, heard that he was not coming and all went to see him.
When the relatives arrived, they only saw their father, wearing the robes of a monk, flying up into the sky.
The son and daughter said:
What is the matter now? Why do you detest your relatives?
While in the sky, he immediately spoke the above verse in reply to his son and daughter.

After speaking the verse, he immediately flew to the Himalayas, where he joined with the pratyekabuddhas. He then returned to the garden where he attained the Way and abandoned his body in parinirvÄá¹‡a.

In general, wise people with mature roots of goodness can attain enlightenment with few causes and conditions.
Wife, children, relatives, and wealth are the faults of birth and death.
Dwelling in the forest, peacefully liberated, like a rhinoceros with a single horn.ğŸ”½I heard it from the Well-Gone One, and passed it on to my teacher.

This minister's son was exceptionally brave and powerful, had many followers, and was arrogant and overbearing due to his self-importance.

In private and secluded places, he secretly plotted slander and said to the prince:
Your uncle, brothers, and relatives are very numerous, yet people often follow the words of their wives.

It is like delicious meat that everyone craves; the royal position is also like this, there is no one who does not covet it.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
It is like water that has not yet arrived; one should work to build bridges and roads.

The prince thought to himself:

At that time, the prince went to his father, the king, and reported the matter in detail.

Having seen this, he thought to himself:
This royal position is extremely evil.
Yet the prime minister and his son secretly instructed my son to act against the way of heaven, wanting to do what is improper.
But my royal position cannot be obtained by them.
My son is now suffering from illness and is about to die. All the people in the world give rise to greed and jealousy.
From this, one should know that the royal position is a contemptible and inferior place.
Why is it contemptible?

Because of the royal position, one abandons good conduct. For the sake of the royal position, one harms one's father and grandfather. For the sake of close friends, one commits great offenses. One abandons shame and remorse, and becomes arrogant. For the sake of little pleasure, one is not afraid of the next world.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Like a moth falling into a blazing fire, one who is blind with greed for the country is also like this.
Deeply attached to gain and loss, doing and not doing,

In the past, in the city of Varanasi, there was a king named Kinsman, who had two chief consorts whom he loved dearly. He indulged in desires, was always heedless, and was addicted like a wild elephant in the Fragrant Mountains, who, when the fragrance flowed out, entered the Malari Mountains and indulged in desires on his own.

After the chief consort took the poison, she became delirious and fell into a deep sleep. She suffered greatly and soon died.
The second chief consort, seeing that she had died, pretended to be distressed. She disheveled her hair, beat her chest and cried, and the entire palace was in mourning.

He then spoke a verse, saying:

9. The youngest son of a wheel-turning sage king realizes pratyekabuddhahood. The youngest son of a wheel-turning sage king realizes pratyekabuddhahood. In the past, innumerable eons ago, there was a wheel-turning sage king with a full thousand sons.

The youngest son saw his father riding on the golden wheel treasure, possessing the seven treasures, with the four divisions of troops as attendants, the drum canopy and decorations all complete. The youngest son then asked his mother,
When will I get to have such things as this canopy and various decorations?
His mother replied,
Even if your bones rot, you still won't get them.
The child then asked,
Why won't I get them?
You have nine hundred and ninety-nine older brothers who should inherit the throne.
According to the order of succession, it will never reach you.
The child then thought,
Since I will not get such decorations, life must end in death, with the body and bones decaying.
Thinking in this way about the faults of birth and death, he immediately became enlightened and attained pratyekabuddhahood, rising into the sky and performing the eighteen transformations.
His mother then invited him again:
Please do not go far, stay in the garden and accept my offerings.
At that time, the pratyekabuddha accepted the invitation of the mothers and stayed in the back garden, receiving offerings from them for many days.
At that time, the pratyekabuddha was tired of having a body, so he abandoned it and entered nirvana.
The mothers, missing him, piled up a large amount of fragrant firewood to cremate his body. They collected his relics and placed them in a jeweled urn, then built a large stupa in the back garden.
At that time, the wheel-turning king was touring the four cities and returned to the back garden, where he saw a large stupa. He found it strange and asked about it.
The garden keeper then said to the king:
This is the youngest son of the king who attained pratyekabuddhahood and entered nirvana here. The mothers built a stupa for him here.
At that time, the wheel-turning king immediately summoned his mother and asked:
Why did my son build this stupa after his death?
Then his mother and others fully informed the king of the matter.
The king reprimanded his mother:
If my son wanted something, why didn't you tell me?
Now that he has entered nirvana, I will place his royal appearance on top of the stupa.
Because of this, for countless kalpas he was always a wheel-turning sage king, enjoying natural blessings that have not yet been exhausted until now.
If he remained in birth and death, he would have been a wheel-turning sage king for 2,500 lifetimes.
Because he attained Buddhahood, he obtained 2,500 jeweled canopies.

Why is it so?
It is to provide for future disciples who lack clothing and food. With this power of blessings, it will cause humans and gods to naturally provide for them.
